instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no image on the screen
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I don't have it's history
it goes to S0 state,

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is present.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LCDVDD_SW</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v 
I am not sure the board is on, but it is in S0 state.
what I have to check next?
thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no image on the screen
threads.message:
"I am not sure the board is on, but it is in S0 state."
Didn't check for external video, or USB activity?

"<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is present."
Why don't you post values?
When board boots, you should note a drop pulse from 1.15V to 0.8V aprox...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no image on the screen
threads.message:
no video on the external lcd 
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.15v 
the board don't boot but stuck in s0 state

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no image on the screen
threads.message:
Check one RAM slot at a time; better with PC3-8500.
You can also try known good working BIOS.
